SUMMARY:
A woman has been reunited with her missing moggy thanks to the power of Tinder.
Supplied Katie Alsop and her cat PeanutThe genius idea came about after Katieâ€™s ginger and white puss, called Peanut, went missing overnight on 11 October.
The next day, Katie was worried sick because she believed her cat might have been murdered by the M25 animal killer (previously known as the Croydon cat killer).
Instead of printing out posters of her missing moggy, Katie decided to download Tinder and pay for a premium membership.
She then went about uploading a photo of herself and Peanut to the app, with information about her beloved cat including reward details.
TEXT:
A woman has been reunited with her missing moggy thanks to the power of Tinder.

Katie Alsop, from Northampton, said she received 400 matches after posting photos of her lost cat on the dating app.

â€œI bought a premium membership, put on a â€˜boostâ€™ to get more attention and uploaded a missing poster with a reward and my number, plus a photo of me and the cat for sympathy,â€ the 26-year-old told HuffPost UK.

After setting her search distance to 10km away, she received a call within 30 minutes from a stranger called Charlie who had found her cat in his garden.

Supplied Katie Alsop and her cat Peanut

The genius idea came about after Katieâ€™s ginger and white puss, called Peanut, went missing overnight on 11 October.

The next day, Katie was worried sick because she believed her cat might have been murdered by the M25 animal killer (previously known as the Croydon cat killer). It played on her mind so much that she had to take a day off work.

Instead of printing out posters of her missing moggy, Katie decided to download Tinder and pay for a premium membership. She then went about uploading a photo of herself and Peanut to the app, with information about her beloved cat including reward details.

Within minutes she was inundated with matches and her beloved cat was eventually located in a nearby estate.

â€œCharlie said he saw my Tinder profile, looked out of his window, and the cat was in his garden! I was so happy he hadnâ€™t been taken by the killer,â€ she added.

But the story doesnâ€™t end there. Peanut escaped from the garden and Katie teamed up with Charlie to track him down.

â€œCharlie was literally scaling 8ft fences and jumping into wasteland, it was like an action film,â€ Katie recalled.

â€œPeanut got scared and headed towards a really busy road so we decided to stop looking for him.â€

In a move that wouldâ€™ve made Hansel and Gretel proud, Katie then made trails of used cat litter around the neighbourhood and back towards her home in the hope her cat would return. When that didnâ€™t work, she added clothes from her laundry basket and warm tuna to the trail.

Much to her delight, the unusual method worked and in the early hours of the morning she heard Peanut meowing in the street.

The 26-year-old has since praised Tinder for helping her track down her catâ€™s whereabouts. She said: â€œI would never have known where to search for Peanut without using Tinder, and really donâ€™t think he would have found his way home on his own.

â€œHeâ€™s never going out again.â€
TITLE: Woman Tracks Down Missing Cat After Uploading Its Photo To Tinder

SUMMARY:
It's about quolls -- those quirky little marsupial predators with a carnivorous diet which may or may not include quiche.
Eastern quolls used to live on the east coast of the Australian mainland (including Queensland) before they quietly quit.
The quoll resettlement is being undertaken by WWF-Australia in conjunction with Rewilding Australia.
The goal is to see some eastern quoll populations permanently re-established in the wild on mainland Australia and it all starts at Booderee National Park."
Rob Brewster from Rewilding Australia said these first quota of quolls would prove which habitat type they prefer.
TEXT:
Today's story is brought to you by the letter q. It's about quolls -- those quirky little marsupial predators with a carnivorous diet which may or may not include quiche.

Eastern quolls used to live on the east coast of the Australian mainland (including Queensland) before they quietly quit.

The quarrelsome cuties now only live in the wild in Tasmania (including near Queenstown). But they're about to be reintroduced to the mainland.

Twenty of the querulous little predators who were bred at Trowunna Wildlife Park and Devils@Cradle sanctuary in Tasmania will be reintroduced to habitat in Booderee National Park in Jervis Bay, New South Wales, about two hours south of Sydney.

There used to be a high quotient of quolls in the area before they were all killed by foxes, cats and other quadrupeds.

Just look at the gorgeous quizzical look on her face.

The quoll resettlement is being undertaken by WWF-Australia in conjunction with Rewilding Australia. They're pups now but by next year they will be adults about to enter their first year of breeding.

But could this turn out to be a quixotic quest? WWF-Australia's Head of Living Ecosystems Darren Grover quashed that line of questioning.

"We hope they settle in quickly, stay healthy and start to breed immediately," he said.

"The loss of native species like eastern quolls has disturbed nature's balance. The goal is to see some eastern quoll populations permanently re-established in the wild on mainland Australia and it all starts at Booderee National Park."

Their features are so quaint.

Rob Brewster from Rewilding Australia said these first quota of quolls would prove which habitat type they prefer.

"This information could become the blueprint for how to re-introduce quolls to other mainland locations," he said.

Meanwhile, WWF-Australia is offering people the opportunity to name the quolls. You can qualify by entering here before November 3. Skip the queue and be quick!

Anyone else just die of cute?
TITLE: Cute Alert: The Quirky Plan To Save Australia's Quarrelsome Quolls

TEXT:
In MÃ¼nchen hat ein Angreifer mehrere Menschen mit einem Messer verletzt

Ein Augenzeuge erzÃ¤hlt "Focus Online" von dem Vorfall

Seine Aussagen kÃ¶nnt ihr in dem Video hÃ¶ren

In MÃ¼nchen hat ein etwa 40 Jahre alter Mann mehrere Menschen mit einem Messer angegriffen. Am Morgen verletzte er an mehreren Orten im MÃ¼nchner Osten Passanten. Offenbar fuhr er mit einem Fahrrad von Tatort zu Tatort.

"Focus Online" hat mit dem Augenzeugen Orhan gesprochen. Er war beruflich in der NÃ¤he und hÃ¶rte Rufe, man mÃ¶ge sofort die Polizei alarmieren.

"Es war furchtbar"

Das Opfer sei "voll mit Blut" gewesen. Er habe ihm ein Taschentuch gegeben und die Polizei gerufen. "Es war furchtbar", sagte Orhan.

Er bedauerte, dass er zu spÃ¤t gekommen sei, um den TÃ¤ter noch verfolgen zu kÃ¶nnen: "WÃ¤re ich eine Minute vorher da gewesen, wÃ¤re ich dem TÃ¤ter hinterhergefahren."

Die HintergrÃ¼nde der Attacke sind derzeit unklar

Am frÃ¼hen Mittag meldete die Polizei, ein Spezialeinsatzkommando habe nach intensiver Fahndung einen VerdÃ¤chtigen festgenommen.

Die HintergrÃ¼nde der Attacke sind derzeit unklar. Laut Bayerns Innenminister Joachim Herrmann (CSU) handelte der Angreifer aus heiterem Himmel.
TITLE: "Voll mit Blut": Passant beschreibt, wie er einem der Opfer der Messer-Attacke in MÃ¼nchen half

TEXT:
When Jan Levinson clapped eyes on her colleagueâ€™s questionable mac and cheese attempt, she simply had to tweet it.

The dish in question was basically a tub filled with cooked macaroni pasta and some grated cheese on the top. (Disappointing to say the least.)

Look at the macaroni & cheese my coworker brought to our potluck today. Bruh. pic.twitter.com/TJ494IFjy5 â€” Jan Levinson (@coolstoryjanis) October 19, 2017

Jan shared photos of the unfortunate creation on Twitter, sending the social media site into hysterics: her tweet was shared more than 10,000 times with 33,000 likes at the time of writing.

She tweeted: â€œLook at the macaroni & cheese my coworker brought to our potluck today. Bruh.â€ (FYI, a potluck is a gathering where people contribute a different type of food theyâ€™ve made).

â€œIâ€™m so offended,â€ Jan added. â€œShe literally poured cooked macaroni into a pot & put shredded cheese on top with not an ounce of seasoning.â€

Cue devastation...

Me at 1 a.m., 12 hours after seeing this: pic.twitter.com/ApAeF8Mmdw â€” Matt Porter (@mattyports) October 19, 2017

This is not mac and cheese. It is mac, with some cheese, touching each other. â€” LibrarianToBe (@YayBooksYay) October 19, 2017

And people urging Jan to get HR involved...

I think you have grounds to file a workplace grievance. https://t.co/Ll31pjxi4o â€” Ava DuVernay (@ava) October 19, 2017

Something is not right there. â€” Bon Blossman (@bonblossman) October 20, 2017

Tell Brenda she needs to report to HR for her exit interview. â€” Melisandre Medici (@_MelisandreM) October 19, 2017

The tweet also prompted people to share stories about their colleaguesâ€™ (often rubbish) attempts at cooking.

Looks like the mess at my husband's office. One lady had fried rice in a Crock-Pot. Do you know what happens to rice in a Crock-Pot? pic.twitter.com/ncjWGka9Xf â€” Christina Jefferson (@tampagirl19655) October 19, 2017

I called into work one time because I heard people got sick after Samantha put olive oil in chicken salad at the company potluck bruh pic.twitter.com/rzXLksuJY4 â€” Shinobi (@MrSmoothNation) October 19, 2017

Once this lady brought mac and cheese. She waited until 11:30 then said, "I need to get it out of my car." pic.twitter.com/cXskc4xcXT â€” Real Facade (@realfacade1) October 20, 2017

One time we had a pot luck, Becky looked like a fashion model. Didn't wash her hands after using the bathroom. Do you want some dessert? pic.twitter.com/ntAF4ToERb â€” Christina Jefferson (@tampagirl19655) October 20, 2017
TITLE: The Internet Is Traumatised By This Awful Mac And Cheese Attempt

SUMMARY:
â€™Stranger Thingsâ€™ is a glorious show, and we couldnâ€™t be more excited about season two landing on Netflix this Friday (27 October).

Hereâ€™s the stages of a hangover, as told by the show.

TEXT:
â€™Stranger Thingsâ€™ is a glorious show, and we couldnâ€™t be more excited about season two landing on Netflix this Friday (27 October). One thing the show is not, however, is good hangover viewing.

Thatâ€™s got nothing to do with its gruesomeness, but more the fact that it mimics the fragile situations we often find ourselves in of a weekend.

Hereâ€™s the stages of a hangover, as told by the show.

1. When you wake up not even knowing your own name

2. When you realise youâ€™ve already slept through the brunch date you arranged with your parents

3. When you have to do the walk of shame

4. When the fear then begins to creep in

5. Then come the flashbacks

6. When you decide to call for reassurance

7. When your mates start filling in the blanks

8. But they just donâ€™t understand the dark, dark place you are in at that moment

9. When you then actually feel worse for having called them

10. When you begin the hunt for your missing dignity

11. When you can no longer ignore the alcohol fumes that are seeping out of every pore

12. When you take a 30-minute shower hoping the water will wash away all the shame

13. When you text that person from Tinder to apologise for the onslaught of drunken messages you left them the night before

14. When you ask your housemates to just hold you gently and quietly

15. When you raid the house for anything and everything to make you feel more human

16. When the Dominos delivery man arrives with your family meal deal you intend on eating just for one

17. When you then regret eating a large pizza, two sides and a drinking whole bottle of Fanta

18. When someone suggests a hair of the dog

19. But then you come round to their way of thinking

20. And before you know it, youâ€™re out again
TITLE: The 20 Stages Of A Hangover As Told By 'Stranger Things'

TEXT:
Emmanuel Macronâ€™s dog has made his stance on politics fairly clear by peeing on a presidential fireplace.

The black labrador-griffon cross, called Nemo, was caught on camera relieving himself against the fireplace in the French presidentâ€™s ornate office at the ElysÃ©e Palace, where Macron was holding a meeting with ministers.

Upon hearing the trickle, the team turned around to see a brazen Nemo with his leg cocked and started cracking up, before junior minister Julien Denormandie managed to ask: â€œDoes that happen often?â€

Macron hastily replied â€˜noâ€™, adding: â€œYouâ€™ve triggered completely unusual behaviour in my dog.â€

The video, which was captured by French TV station TF1, has been widely shared on social media, with Nemo becoming something of an internet hero.

Very good dog deals with a potential fire hazard saving the lives of many ğŸ¶ğŸ”¥ https://t.co/PqEYeOgRcP â€” Viv Heaton (@viv_heaton) October 22, 2017

Macron's dog: 0 fucks given. â€” R. W. Abel (@Stolidoggon) October 23, 2017

Macronâ€™s dog knew exactly what he was doing #bbcbreakfast â€” â¬‡Top tweet as always (@gxzs) October 23, 2017

Turns out this kind of thing isnâ€™t just the unfortunate reserve of French politicians, according to former Home Secretary Jacqui Smith who tweeted in solidarity.

Nemo Macron should be reassured that I once sat in a Cabinet meeting with a cat poo under the table behind me! https://t.co/8mhvBoZ74y â€” Jacqui Smith (@Jacqui_Smith1) October 22, 2017
TITLE: Emmanuel Macron's Dog Nemo Wees On Presidential Fireplace During Meeting

TITLE: Quirk

SUMMARY:
Men are responding to #MeToo by posting admissions of guilt, using the hashtag #ItWasMe.
If we are going to end sexism, men must be involved, and #ItWasMe is a sign many are stepping up and taking responsibility.
If men think these types of posts are helping, they're wrong.
Why are men posting these statuses?
But before you post an #ItWasMe status, please think about why you're posting it and who you are posting it for.
TEXT:
In the wake of the Harvey Weinstein allegations, the hashtag #MeToo has been a powerful tool enabling women to share their experiences of sexual harassment and assault. It's allowed us to show naysayers once and for all that rape culture does exist, it isn't a fictional concept invented by "angry feminists".

My own newsfeed has been filled with women sharing their stories or simply posting those two powerful words, and the fact that both men and women have commented to thank them for speaking out has given me hope for a better future.

But now, a second hashtag is doing the rounds that's left me feeling both vulnerable and infuriated.

Men are responding to #MeToo by posting admissions of guilt, using the hashtag #ItWasMe. The hashtag is used by men wishing to identify themselves as either a perpetrator or bystander of sexual assault or harassment, with a promise to do better. A typical tweet might read something like: "I've catcalled women, I've groped women in clubs. I'm sorry. I will do better #ItWasMe."

Let me start by saying it's great that #MeToo has led to men rethinking their own behaviour. If we are going to end sexism, men must be involved, and #ItWasMe is a sign many are stepping up and taking responsibility. But while the majority of #ItWasMe statuses are positive, there are some that could have devastating effects.

Some of the longer #ItWasMe admissions, particularly those posted on Facebook, contain information that makes the women spoken about identifiable.

In one example I've read a man describes his guilt about pressuring his ex-girlfriend into having sex with him when she explicitly said she wasn't ready to. The man provides details of himself and his then-girlfriend, such as their ages.

If you are friends with this man, you may well know who he dated in his late teens. If you went to school or university together, you may even still be friends with his ex-girlfriend on Facebook. That woman may not want you to know that someone pressured her into having sex.

For a start, public discussion about the incident could be triggering for the woman involved. As numerous articles have pointed out over the past few days, women shouldn't feel pressured to share their #MeToo experiences. For some it may be cathartic, but for others it could be traumatic.

Sadly, there is also a culture of shame that follows harassment and assault that means many of us choose to stay silent. I write about personal experiences of catcalling, nightclub groping and everyday sexism on a regular basis, but there is one past incident I never touch on. Because I'm not ready to. Because it's still painful to think about. Because I don't want to change the way my friends and family think about me. And because that's my choice. To have that choice taken away from me by the perpetrator posting an #ItWasMe status would feel like being violated all over again. If men think these types of posts are helping, they're wrong.

The second issue I have with some of the #ItWasMe posts is the language used, because in some instances it only risks fuelling misconceptions about assault and harassment.

Two posts that riled me up include the phrases such as "I had sex with her when she didn't want to" and "I tried to penetrate her [while she was asleep]".

To make things clear: there is no such thing as "sex" with a woman who doesn't want to have sex. It's rape. If you tried (but failed) to penetrate a woman while she was asleep, that's attempted rape. Let's call these crimes what they are and stop sending men mixed messages about consent.

As a side note, these men have also potentially opened themselves up to prosecution in the future. I'm no lawyer, but I'd hazard a guess that if you've admitted you're guilty of rape on Facebook, then a woman decides to prosecute, telling a jury you didn't understand the language you were using may not wash.

My final grievance with these statuses is the sanctimonious tone of some of them. Posting a status stating that you have never harassed a woman but apologising if you have ever been a bystander feels disingenuous. It feels like the most half-assed kind of apology there is, like when celebrities say "I'm sorry if anyone was offended" rather than simply saying "I'm sorry". Why are men posting these statuses? It's not an admission of guilt, it's not even really a promise to try harder, so I can only assume you are posting this to get a few likes and boost your own ego.

Again, I want to stress that I am not talking about all #ItWasMe posts. Many have been created sensitively and it is uplifting to see men finally take part in a conversation about sexual harassment - something that's been seen as a "women's issue" for far too long.

But before you post an #ItWasMe status, please think about why you're posting it and who you are posting it for. Take a step back and look at the language you've used. Can a woman be identified? Are you whitewashing assault with euphemisms? If you want to join the movement, your status is just as valid if you post those three words, and nothing else.

Alternatively, check out the hashtag #HowIWillChange. Instead of dragging up incidents from the past that could do more harm than good, the movement looks towards the future. The hashtag is full of men promising to never catcall a woman again, committing to never touch a woman's body without her permission and insisting they will speak up next time they hear a sexist comment. We've done a lot of talking about sexual assault and harassment over the last few days, but if we truly want to enable a culture shift, it's time for positive action.
TITLE: Why Men Need To Be Cautious About Tweeting #ItWasMe

SUMMARY:
A huge new Mario Kart-inspired raceway is opening up in Niagara Falls, and it's one of the first of its kind.
The track is similar to the one in Branson, Missouri which has three different go-kart courses modelled around the famous video game.
First launched in 1992, Mario was originally a spin-off from Nintendo's more successful Super Mario video games.
Thirteen games in the series have been produced, with the latest one, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe, being released in April 2017.
Check out some of pics of the track -- and its sister track in Branson -- below:
TEXT:
The track is one of the first of its kind.

A huge new Mario Kart-inspired raceway is opening up in Niagara Falls, and it's one of the first of its kind.

Called the 'Niagara Speedway', the track will feature a corkscrew section that reaches more than ten metres high, and a number of elevated sections that will make you feel like you're on Rainbow Road or racing through Bowser's Castle.

The track is similar to the one in Branson, Missouri which has three different go-kart courses modelled around the famous video game.

Built by HOCO Entertainment and Resorts, the tracks aims to revitalise flagging Niagara tourism.

First launched in 1992, Mario was originally a spin-off from Nintendo's more successful Super Mario video games.



But the car-racing game took on a cult-like status over the years -- it has sold more than 100 million copies worldwide. Thirteen games in the series have been produced, with the latest one, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe, being released in April 2017.

The track will open in 2018.

Check out some of pics of the track -- and its sister track in Branson -- below:
TITLE: A Life-Size Mario Kart Track Is About To Open In Niagara Falls

Alle Tipps des Discounters erfahrt ihr im Video oben

Damit das in der Zukunft nicht mehr passiert, hat der Discounter Aldi SÃ¼d, auf seinem Unternehmens-Blog, Tipps fÃ¼rs Schlangestehen an der Kasse gegeben.

Tipp 1: Folge den Einkaufswagen

Besteht die Schlange aus Menschen mit Einkaufswagen statt mit KÃ¶rben oder TÃ¼ten? Das soll schon einmal ein gutes Zeichen sein. Artikel aufs Band zu legen und dann wieder zurÃ¼ck in den Wagen gehe demnach deutlich schneller, als dasselbe mit einer EinkaufstÃ¼te.

Tipp 2: Hinter Jemanden mit vollem Einkaufswagen anstellen

TatsÃ¤chlich rÃ¤t der Discounter seinen Kunden, sich hinter Menschen mit vollen Einkaufswagen zu stellen. Berechnungen haben nÃ¤mlich gezeigt, dass es viel lÃ¤nger dauere, viele Kunden mit wenigen Artikeln zu kassieren als wenige Kunden mit vielen Artikeln. BegrÃ¼ÃŸung, Bezahlen und Einpacken nehme meist mehr Zeit in Anspruch als der eigentliche Kassiervorgang.

Tipp 3: An der linken Kasse anstellen

Laut Aldi-SÃ¼d sollen sich Kunden meist automatisch an die Kasse anstellen, die sich weiter rechts befindet. Das soll damit zu tun haben, dass viele Leute RechtshÃ¤nder sind. Daher: Nehmt die linke Schlange!

TEXT:
Die SPD soll "jÃ¼nger und weiblicher" werden

SPD-Chef Martin Schulz gab am Montag wichtige Personalentscheidungen bekannt

"JÃ¼nger und weiblicher" erscheint seine Partei allerdings kaum

Die SPD will Erneuerung.

Nach dem schwÃ¤chsten Bundestagswahlergebnis der Parteigeschichte haben sich die Sozialdemokraten vorgenommen, ihre Partei in der Opposition neu aufzustellen. "JÃ¼nger und weiblicher" solle die Partei werden, betonte auch SPD-Chef Martin Schulz am Montag zum wiederholten Mal.

Die Personalentscheidung, die er im Willy-Brandt-Haus in Berlin verkÃ¼ndete, soll diese Vision unterstreichen. Der SPD-Digitalexperte Lars Klingbeil soll als GeneralsekretÃ¤r die Erneuerung der krisengeplagten Partei voranbringen. Klingbeil ist 39 Jahre alt â€” damit verkÃ¶rpert er eine neue Generation in der Partei.

Doch damit nicht genug: Auch die neue Fraktionschefin Andrea Nahles sei eine "junge Frau", erklÃ¤rte Schulz. Nahles ist 47, seit 14 Jahren Mitglied des SPD-PrÃ¤sidiums. Dass sie als jung gilt, verrÃ¤t viel Ã¼ber die Abwesenheit junger Stimmen auf Parlamentsebene.

Die Mitglieder der SPD-Fraktion im Bundestag sind durchschnittlich 50 Jahre alt. Nur die AfD mit durchschnittlich etwa 51 Jahren stellt Ã¤ltere Abgeordnete.

Der Bundestag kommt morgen zur konstituierenden Sitzung zusammen @dpa_infografik mit einem Blick in den Plenarsaal - korrigierte Fassung/him pic.twitter.com/wRuBewZ6Vh â€” dpa (@dpa) 23. Oktober 2017

Die SPD wird weiblicher? Mitnichten!

Auch das Unterfangen, die SPD weiblicher zu gestalten, treibt Schulz bisweilen mit eher mÃ¤ÃŸigem Erfolg voran. Mit Klingbeil Ã¼bernimmt wieder ein Mann den wichtigen Posten des GeneralsekretÃ¤rs. Auch der neue Parlamentarische GeschÃ¤ftsfÃ¼hrer ist mit Carsten Schneider ein Mann.

Zwei Frauen erteilten Schulz derweil einen Korb. Ãœberschattet wurde Klingbeils Vorstellung noch dazu vom Abgang der SPD-BundesgeschÃ¤ftsfÃ¼hrerin Juliane Seifert. Sie kÃ¼ndigte am Montag ihren sofortigen RÃ¼ckzug an, nachdem sich Schulz intern auf die Suche nach einer Nachfolgerin fÃ¼r sie gemacht hatte und dies an die Ã–ffentlichkeit gedrungen war.

Am Freitag war bekannt geworden, dass Schulz die Noch-Juso-Chefin Johanna Uekermann zur neuen BundesgeschÃ¤ftsfÃ¼hrerin hatte machen wollen - doch die lehnte ab.

Schulz hatte mit Uekermanns Berufung auch ein VersÃ¶hnungszeichen an die Frauen und die Linken in der SPD senden wollen. Die fÃ¼hlen sich bei den jÃ¼ngsten Personalentscheidungen in Partei und Fraktion nicht ausreichend berÃ¼cksichtigt.

Schulz' Taktik ging jedoch nicht auf: Uekermann lehnte das Angebot ab, Seifert wurde Ã¶ffentlich bloÃŸgestellt, und der Posten bleibt nun vorerst unbesetzt.

In der SPD gibt es bereits seit Jahren Diskussionen, wie die Partei auch fÃ¼r Frauen wieder attraktiver werden kann. Die Abgeordnete Cansel Kiziltepe kritisierte zuletzt in der HuffPost: "Wir mÃ¼ssen jÃ¼nger und weiblicher werden. Wir sind, was Frauen angeht, eigentlich nicht wÃ¤hlbar.â€œ Nur etwa ein Drittel der Parteimitglieder sind Frauen.

Dieser Montag hat sicherlich nicht dazu beigetragen, einen echten VerÃ¤nderungswillen zu signalisieren.

"Die SPD hat in den letzten Tagen kein gutes Bild abgegeben", rÃ¤umte Schulz ein. "DafÃ¼r bin ich als Vorsitzender naturgemÃ¤ÃŸ mit verantwortlich."

Mit Material der dpa.
TITLE: Schulz spricht Ã¼ber die "junge, weibliche" SPD - und offenbart, wie schlecht seine Partei aufgestellt ist

SUMMARY:
Three weeks ago, Gigaba stuck his hand into your money and handed SAA another R3-billion.
That's 136 children per month, or more than four a day, dying of hunger right here in our own country.
The same government that will throw R35-billion at a failing airline tells us there simply isn't enough money to stop four children per day from starving to death.
We won't be the first country to give up its national airline, and we certainly won't be the last either.
Life will carry on after SAA, but only with more money for the poor and less for the corrupt.
TEXT:
On Wednesday, Finance Minister Malusi Gigaba will present us with his medium-term budget policy statement. Then we will get to see whether he will offer South Africa a Gupta budget designed to prop up a failing ANC, or a budget that serves the poor and marginalised of our country.

Judging by Gigaba's track record in all his Cabinet positions, I am not holding my breath for the latter. Because, to date, he has shown no capacity to serve the interest of the people. All he has shown us is that he is there to do the bidding of Zuma's handlers, the Guptas. That he is a captured man.

Three weeks ago, Gigaba stuck his hand into your money and handed SAA another R3-billion. Three months earlier he did the same, this time R2.2-billion. And this R5.2-billion is just half of what is needed to keep the airline aloft this financial year.

If you look back at past bailouts given to the airline since 1999, that amount goes up to R19-billion. And if you include the government guarantees -- money that taxpayers will fork out if Eskom can't pay its debts -- then we're talking about a massive R35-billion. Under the "leadership" of Dudu Myeni -- and I use the word leadership in its loosest possible sense -- this airline has made a loss of almost R16-billion over the past five years.

During her time as chairperson, SAA failed in every way to deliver on its mandate. I would describe her as a delinquent director. Thank goodness she is finally gone, and not a moment too soon. But the basic question that no one in government is able to answer is this: why?

Why are we doing this? Why are we keeping this airline going with massive bailout after massive bailout, when it clearly serves no helpful purpose to ordinary South Africans at all? Why keep subsidising the comparatively wealthy who can afford to fly, at the expense of the very poor and the unemployed? Why do we have to keep saving SAA? No one in government can answer this.

Our parastatals have become massive ATMs from which the leeches who feast on our precious resources suck money every month.

On Thursday, Deputy President Cyril Ramaphosa said that SAA is a "national asset". I would have thought a businessman like Cyril would know the difference between an asset and a liability. Let us also not forget that Ramaphosa chaired the interministerial committee on state-owned enterprises, but was not willing to implement any measures to curb the mismanagement.

No, Mister Deputy President, calling SAA a national asset is not a good enough answer. Not a single person in government can answer the basic question of why we should keep saving SAA. So let me give you the answer. We are propping up the failing SAA because it's just another great place for cadres and cronies to make lots of money.

Our parastatals have become massive ATMs from which the leeches who feast on our precious resources suck money every month. This is done not only with the knowledge of our government, but with their assistance. And all evidence points to Gigaba as the man appointed to hand over the keys to our nation's wealth. That's why we keep being forced to bail out SAA. Let's just be honest.

And dealing with the anger of the public and the fallout in the media when these stories break is seen as a small price to pay for all that wealth. That's why you and I and every South African continue to fund this endless corruption, bailout after bailout.

People ask: What is the effect of corruption? Who are its victims? Let me tell you who they are. Earlier this year, in answer to a Parliamentary question, the department of health said that 4,900 children under the age of five had died over the past three years in South Africa owing to severe acute malnutrition. Let that sink in.

That's 136 children per month, or more than four a day, dying of hunger right here in our own country. And they're dying because their mothers cannot feed them on the R380 per month they're given as a child-support grant. When asked why the child support grant is just R380 a month, the minister said: That's all the money there is.

Are four starving children a day not a big enough problem for us to consider stopping these endless multi-billion Rand bailouts and diverting the money instead towards our social safety net?

The same government that will throw R35-billion at a failing airline tells us there simply isn't enough money to stop four children per day from starving to death. How, friends? How is this acceptable in South Africa in 2017?

Must we accept this and go on with our lives? Are four starving children per day not a big enough problem for us to consider stopping these endless multibillion-rand bailouts and diverting the money instead towards our social safety net?

Or should we feel angry about it? Should we refuse to accept this government's criminal priorities? I know what my answer is.

Fellow South Africans, we don't need to carry on propping up a national carrier for the sake of a corrupt elite, at the cost of millions of desperately poor South Africans. We must let it go.

SAA must be placed into business rescue until it has stabilised, and then it must be dismantled and sold. The vast sums of money we will save can be ploughed straight back into any number of programmes that directly benefit the poor.

We won't be the first country to give up its national airline, and we certainly won't be the last either. In a globally competitive world, the most efficient, cost-effective players will quickly step in and fill the gaps. Life will carry on after SAA, but only with more money for the poor and less for the corrupt. Which is the way it should be.

Maimane is the leader of the Democratic Alliance.
TITLE: We Canâ€™t Throw Billions At SAA While Four Children Per Day Die Of Starvation In SA

TEXT:
An Amazon corporate office building in Sunnyvale, Calif. Amazon says it has received 238 proposals from cities and regions across North America vying to host the company's second headquarters.

Oct 23 (Reuters) â€” Amazon.com Inc has received 238 proposals from cities and regions across North America vying to host the company's second headquarters, it said on Monday.

The number of applicants underscores the interest in the contest, which Seattle-based Amazon announced last month. The world's largest online retailer said it would invest more than US$5 billion and create up to 50,000 jobs for "Amazon HQ2". The deadline for submitting proposals was Thursday.

Amazon said 54 states, provinces, districts and territories in the United States, Canada and Mexico were represented in the bids.

Watch: Amazon offered billions for HQ2

The Canadian cities of Toronto, Ottawa-Gatineau, Edmonton, Calgary, Halifax, Sault Ste. Marie, Windsor (with Detroit), Hamilton, Montreal and Vancouver submitted bids, according to Reuters' reporting and local media reports.

Some said this month they could offer Amazon billions of dollars in tax breaks if they were chosen. New Jersey proposed $7 billion in potential credits against state and city taxes if Amazon locates in Newark and sticks to hiring commitments, for instance.

Amazon did not disclose the range of incentives it was offered in the proposals.

Others took different tactics. The mayor of the Atlanta suburb of Stonecrest, Jason Lary, said his city would use 345 acres of industrial land to create a new city called Amazon. Amazon Chief Executive Jeff Bezos would be its mayor for life, Lary said.

Amazon is expected to choose a city that will help it recruit top talent to stay competitive with rivals such as Alphabet Inc's Google.

The company has said it will make a decision next year.

â€” With additional reporting from Reuters

Also on HuffPost:
TITLE: Amazon's 'HQ2' Race Attracts 238 Bidding Cities And Regions

TEXT:
Fun Is Not Just For Kids - And For Good Reason You'll see plenty of children and young people at Fun Palaces this coming weekend - after all, we live in a society that tells us fun is only for kids - but hopefully you'll also see the grownups getting stuck in, learning, sharing, playing too. The Urban Island Music has always been central to my life. From battle rapping in the playground, to signing a record deal or two, being on tour, then spending a few years as a publicist, I have always had a fascination for the industry and the mechanics of how an artist is discovered, nurtured and then released into the world... Radio presenter, BC Radio 5 live and Asian Network

PROMOTED BY OLDMOUT The Mission To Save New Zealand's Beloved Kiwi Birds The adorable, long-beaked kiwi bird is in great danger of extinction. There are only 50,000 kiwi birds left on our planet and the number is falling quickly - the small population has declined by 99% in the past 80 years alone. Zoology grad interested in environmental issues and animal conservation

Six Steps To Make Happiness Stick You know you want to be happy and you know it's important for your wellbeing. However, you're confused and unclear about how to actually get to happiness. This isn't surprising as there are so many myths and messages being shouted from the rooftops. Also known as Happyologist, helps individuals, teams and organisations find their best performance through helping them become more passionate, positive and proactive

If Universal Credit Rollout Continues, Foodbanks Won't Be Able To Catch Everyone Who Falls What we must not become is a charity safety net that catches people because our benefits system is fundamentally flawed. My Brittle Bone Condition Won't Stop Me Living Life To The Full My name is Samantha Renke and I am a Lancashire-born actress and public speaker who currently lives in east London. I am a former teacher and trustee for the brittle bone society. I have a genetic condition called osteogenesis imperfecta, more commonly known as brittle bones condition which means I am a full-time wheelchair user, but this most certainly doesn't stop me from living life to the full. This World Alzheimer's Day - and beyond it - let's do everything in our power to make sure people don't have to face dementia alone. Let's speak up and speak out about dementia so awareness and understanding across society is improved. Let's come together and unite against dementia. If you have a loved one with dementia, spend time with them. Love them, the same way you always have. Actress and Alzheimerâ€™s Society ambassador

Almost all houses have been destroyed, there is no food, no water and no electricity. My severe disappointment in the UK Government's response to this disaster was only overcome by the extreme altruism and genuine concern for human life and dignity that I've witnessed from all those who care about the BVI and the people in it. How We're Turning Grenfell Donations Into Cash For Victims In the immediate aftermath of the Grenfell Tower fire, dozens of people started to arrive at the local rest centres with bottles of water, bags of bedding, clothing, children's toys, anything they could muster to help those who had lost everything. Very quickly, those dozens of people turned into a community, then a city, and before the day was out the whole country was donating items to the fire victims. Everyone wanted to do something to help. It was a huge spontaneous response to what has been one of the UK's worst peacetime disasters. Chief Executive at the British Red Cross

British-Syrian doctor and Founder of CanDo.

SUMMARY:
After withering criticism for naming Zimbabweâ€™s leader, Robert Mugabe, as a â€œgoodwill ambassador,â€ the World Health Organization announced on Sunday that it had rescinded the appointment.
Here is Human Rights Watch on President Mugabeâ€™.
Why Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe is now the shortest-serving World Health Organization (@WHO) goodwill ambassador.
â€œThe inordinate noise around the designation of President [Mugabe] â€¦ does not assist the cause in the first place.
If anything, it is WHO that has benefited tremendously from its decision in nominating President Mugabe,â€ said Foreign Minister Walter Mzembi, according to South Africaâ€™s Independent Online.
TEXT:
After withering criticism for naming Zimbabweâ€™s leader, Robert Mugabe, as a â€œgoodwill ambassador,â€ the World Health Organization announced on Sunday that it had rescinded the appointment.

â€œI have listened carefully to all who have expressed their concerns and heard the different issues that they have raised,â€ Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHOâ€™s director general, said in a statement. â€œI have also consulted with the government of Zimbabwe and we have concluded that this decision is in the best interests of the World Health Organization.â€

Just five days earlier, Ghebreyesus had said he was â€œhonoredâ€ to appoint Mugabe as ambassador. He also claimed the Zimbabwean leader â€” whose decades-long rule has been characterized by authoritarianism and corruption â€” would focus on the issue of noncommunicable diseases in Africa. Speaking at a conference in Uruguay, Ghebreyesus expressed hope that Mugabe would â€œinfluence his peers in his region to prioritize [non-communicable diseases],â€ including heart attacks, cancer and diabetes.

The global condemnation of this choice was swift and staggering. The State Department said Mugabeâ€™s appointment â€œclearly contradicts the United Nationsâ€™ ideals of respect for human rights and human dignity.â€ Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau compared the choice to â€œa bad April Foolâ€™s joke.â€ Irelandâ€™s health minister, Simon Harris, called the nomination â€œoffensiveâ€ and â€œbizarre.â€ And Richard Horton, editor-in-chief of The Lancet, said WHO was â€œendorsing a repressive dictator.â€

Dear Tedros - You must rescind your decision. Here is Human Rights Watch on President Mugabeâ€™. You are endorsing a repressive dictator. pic.twitter.com/dB4qpq1zZp â€” richard horton (@richardhorton1) October 21, 2017

More than two dozen health organizations, including the World Heart Federation and NCD Alliance, said in a joint statement that they were â€œshockedâ€ by the appointment.

â€œWhile we recognize that President Mugabe was the only African Head of State to accept the invitation to attend the WHO Global Conference and has made commitments to prioritize NCDs in his country, nevertheless â€¦ [we] are shocked and deeply concerned to hear of this appointment, given President Mugabeâ€™s long track record of human rights violations and undermining the dignity of human beings,â€ the statement read.

Why Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe is now the shortest-serving World Health Organization (@WHO) goodwill ambassador. pic.twitter.com/6TJ8PopJqd â€” Al Jazeera English (@AJEnglish) October 22, 2017

Mugabe, 93, did expand health care in Zimbabwe in the first two decades of his rule, but the health system has suffered enormously since 2000, when the Zimbabwean economy collapsed.

â€œStaff often go without pay, medicines are in short supply, and Mugabe, who has outlived the average life expectancy in his country by three decades, travels abroad for medical treatment,â€ the BBC reported.

In July, Mugabe flew to Singapore for the third time this year for medical treatment. Singapore â€œis literally his home now,â€ said an opposition party spokesman at the time, per The Guardian.

Reacting to the change, Mugabeâ€™s government said Monday that it was the WHO and the global community that would lose most from the decision.

â€œThe inordinate noise around the designation of President [Mugabe] â€¦ does not assist the cause in the first place. If anything, it is WHO that has benefited tremendously from its decision in nominating President Mugabe,â€ said Foreign Minister Walter Mzembi, according to South Africaâ€™s Independent Online.

Other Zimbabweans expressed delight at the news. Opposition leader Tendai Biti said he was â€œrelievedâ€ that the appointment had been revoked, reported Independent Online.
TITLE: Facing Global Outrage, WHO Revokes Robert Mugabe's Goodwill Ambassador Appointment

SUMMARY:
FAZCINATING DINNER CHATWhen Jean-Claude Juncker and Theresa May met for a Brexit dinner in April, a rather unhelpful read-out was given to the German newspaper FAZ.
The Sunday edition of FAZ â€“ the Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung â€“ published details of Mayâ€™s dinner with Juncker last Monday.
The EU Commission â€“ headed by Juncker â€“ is reportedly putting the bill at over 60billion, while the Donald Tusk-led European Council is holding out for 90billion.
TIME ISNâ€™T MONEYAn overwhelming majority of the British public would support a ban on unpaid internships, according to the Social Mobility Commission.
Social Mobility Commission chairman, former Labour cabinet minister Alan Milburn, said: â€œUnpaid internships are a modern scandal which must end.
TEXT:
JULIEN WARNAND via Getty Images

1. FAZCINATING DINNER CHAT

When Jean-Claude Juncker and Theresa May met for a Brexit dinner in April, a rather unhelpful read-out was given to the German newspaper FAZ.

It claimed Juncker thought May was â€œliving in another galaxyâ€ and â€œdeluding herselfâ€ over the Brexit negotiations â€“ statements which prompted the UK Prime Minister to accuse the EU of using â€œthreatsâ€ to undermine the election in her now infamous speech in Downing Street.

Six months on from that first dinner, and itâ€™s de ja vu all over again. The Sunday edition of FAZ â€“ the Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung â€“ published details of Mayâ€™s dinner with Juncker last Monday.

Compared to six months ago, the article contains more sorrow than anger. Juncker is reported to be telling colleagues that May has â€œdeep ringsâ€ under her eyes and is â€œdrawn from the struggle with her own party.â€ She is â€œanxious, despondent and disheartenedâ€ and only manages to smile for the cameras.

The report claims May made â€œhelpâ€ calls to Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron, and the dinner with Juncker was arranged at â€œthe last minuteâ€ â€“ something which Downing Street denied when pressed on last week.

On the details of Brexit, the report makes clear that while May is keen to get the transition phase locked down, the EU is still very much focused on the money. Yet they canâ€™t even agree amongst themselves how much Britain should pay. The EU Commission â€“ headed by Juncker â€“ is reportedly putting the bill at over 60billion, while the Donald Tusk-led European Council is holding out for 90billion.

Amongst all the talk about money, transitions and Mayâ€™s tired eyes, there is a line in the piece which shows the EU are realising why they need to give the Prime Minister something to show for the negotiations. â€œBetter to negotiate with a realistic May than with the dream dancer Johnson,â€ is the thinking, showing the Foreign Secretaryâ€™s recent interventions might actually be helping, not hindering, the PM.

When the article was published, Mayâ€™s former advisor Nick Timothy was quick to lay the blame at the door of Junckerâ€™s closest confident Martin Selmayr â€“ a civil servant who is head of the EU Commission Presidentâ€™s cabinet.

â€œAfter constructive Council meeting, Selmayr does this. Reminder that some in Brussels want no deal or a punitive one,â€ Timothy tweeted.

May will be giving her own version of recent events with a statement in the Commons at 3.30pm.

Want to know whatâ€™s really going on with Brexit? Sign up for HuffPost UKâ€™s Brexit Briefing - sent straight to your inbox every Thursday.

2. BUSINESSES ARE UNPHASED

Last weekâ€™s European Summit saw the EU27 give an inch on moving to trade talks, but there is a reminder today that the business world wanted to see a mile.

A letter co-authored by the CBI, the British Chambers of Commerce, the manufacturing trade body EEF, the Institute of Directors and the Federation of Small Businesses is urging David Davis to get the post-March 2019 transition phase agreed as soon as possible.

Seen by The Guardian, the letter reminds the Brexit Secretary that businesses â€œneed agreement of transitional arrangements as soon as possible, as without urgent agreement many companies have serious decisions about investment and contingency plans to take at the start of 2018.â€

It adds: â€œFailure to agree a transition period of at least two years could have wide-reaching and damaging consequences for investment and trade, as firms review their investment plans and business strategies.â€

With the Goldman Sachs CEO tweeting last week he would be spending more time in Frankfurt after Brexit â€“ presumably not just to enjoy the numerous historic cathedrals â€“ the pressure is growing for the Government to give reassurances to business that the UK is not heading for a cliff-edge in 17 months time.

The EUâ€™s mantra â€“ which Davis has repeated on numerous occasions â€“ that â€˜nothing is agreed until everything is agreedâ€™ may well need to be challenged.

3. SPREAD-THIN PHIL

Away from Brexit, and domestic eyes are increasingly been drawn to Philip Hammondâ€™s make-or-break Budget on November 22.

The under-fire Chancellor is having to walk the tightrope of appeasing those in his party who want to see the spending taps turned on, and those who still think the whole plumbing system has too many leaks.

Hammond â€“ along with many other Cabinet ministers â€“ has been in listening mode since Parliament returned after the summer, holding a series of meetings with backbenchers to listen to their ideas.

Earlier this month I reported how some were getting a â€˜safety firstâ€™ message from Hammond, suggesting there would be no high-profile spending announcements, especially in light of the OBR dialing down its previous growth estimates.

After that report, there were briefings that Hammond would indeed push on with more spending.

It all gives the impression of Phil not quite knowing which formulas to use in his famous spreadsheets.

The Times is leading today with the story that Hammond is doomed to failure no matter what he does, with Brexiteer Tories looking to use his Budget as an excuse to oust him. Cabinet members are lining up to replace him, according to the report, with several using last weekâ€™s meeting in Downing Street as an audition to by the next Chancellor

Communities Secretary Sajid Javid tried to write his own Budget on the Andrew Marr show yesterday, saying â€œwhere we can sensibly borrow more to invest in infrastructure that leads to more housing being built, and take advantage of some of the record low interest rates, I think we should absolutely be considering it.â€

The Sun are reporting today that Javid wants the Treasury to borrow Â£50billion to fund a house building programme.

On the Westminster Hour last night, backbencher Jacob Rees-Mogg gave the opposite view, saying borrowing money to build houses is â€œtackling the wrong end of the problemâ€.

The Moggster believes it is the planning system which is stopping enough houses being built, describing it as â€œcompletely gummed up.â€

Interestingly, Rees-Mogg â€“ who you would assume would be a staunch defender of Britainâ€™s green and pleasant land â€“ suggested more building should take place on the green belt.

â€œI think the electorate is ahead of the politicians. They recognise that we have such a housing problem that building on green fields is extremely welcome and recognised as being necessary,â€ he said.

BECAUSE YOUâ€™VE READ THIS FAR...

Iâ€™m sure this is somehow a metaphor for the recent General Election, with Theresa May as the goalkeeper...

4. WONâ€™T SOMEBODY THINK OF THE CHILDRENâ€™S CENTRES?

If all politics is local, then Hammond would do well to listen to the concerns of Tory councillors as he plans his Budget.

Nearly three quarters of Conservative councillors are worried about government funding cuts to childrenâ€™s centres, a new poll has revealed.

The research, which saw 508 Tory local government representatives quizzed by charity Action for Children, showed 72% believe long-term funding for childrenâ€™s services is a major concern for their council.

More than half say budget restrictions are making it harder for councils to meet their responsibilities towards children and young people, while 38% believe there is a â€œlack of clear direction and fundingâ€ from government.

Sir Tony Hawkhead, chief executive of Action for Children, said: â€œOur findings show the growing fear that the government is failing in its pledge to give all children the best start in life.â€

One Conservative council cabinet member who took part in the survey said the impact of further cuts would be â€œsignificantâ€ and that their local authority had already been forced to scrap some family support services.

But campaigners hoping for a reversal to the trend which has seen 350 Sure Start centres closed since 2010 might not want to hold their breath. The Tory Government didnâ€™t even step in to keep open the centre which David Cameronâ€™s mother volunteered in. The Chieveley and Area Childrenâ€™s Centre in Berkshire where Mary Cameron helped out was shut in 2016.

5. TIME ISNâ€™T MONEY

An overwhelming majority of the British public would support a ban on unpaid internships, according to the Social Mobility Commission.

A new poll of nearly 5,000 people shows 72% would back a change in the law preventing companies from exploiting unpaid interns â€“ with 42% â€œstrongly supportingâ€ a ban.

The survey also reveals 80% of people want to see a clampdown on nepotism - with businesses being made to openly advertise internships and work experience opportunities, rather than organise them through informal networks.

Its results have been released ahead of a second reading of a private membersâ€™ bill in the House of Lords this week, which proposes a ban on unpaid work experience or internships lasting more than four weeks.

Social Mobility Commission chairman, former Labour cabinet minister Alan Milburn, said: â€œUnpaid internships are a modern scandal which must end.

â€œInternships are the new rung on the career ladder. They have become a route to a good professional job. But access to them tends to depend on who, not what, you know, and young people from low-income backgrounds are excluded because they are unpaid.â€

SUNDAY SHOWS ROUND-UP

Had a lie-in? Got a life? Catch up with the Sunday political shows you missed with our quick round-up HERE.
TITLE: The Waugh Zone, Monday October 23, 2017

FRONT NATIONAL - C'est l'un des chantiers les plus emblÃ©matiques de la "refondation historique" du Front national promise par Marine Le Pen. PressÃ©e de tourner la page de ses dÃ©convenues Ã©lectorales, la prÃ©sidente du parti d'extrÃªme droite poursuit sa tournÃ©e. Elle se dÃ©place ce dimanche 22 octobre dans le Morbihan.

AuprÃ¨s de ses militants, Marine Le Pen doit notamment proposer de changer le nom de leur formation politique. Objectif assumÃ© de cette "tournÃ©e pour un nouveau front": sortir de la culture contestataire du Front pour tenter d'incarner, d'ici cinq ans, une force politique capable de gouverner.

Â« Quelle joie d'Ãªtre en terre de #Bretagne, terre de ma famille, ce pays breton cher Ã  mon cÅ“ur ! Â» #Morbihan #TournÃ©eMLP pic.twitter.com/8K8xs7d03u â€” Marine Le Pen (@MLP_officiel) 22 octobre 2017

Un tel changement serait une "imbÃ©cillitÃ© criminelle" a d'ores et dÃ©jÃ  Ã©cartÃ© Jean-Marie Le Pen, trÃ¨s attachÃ© Ã  la marque FN qu'il a contribuÃ© Ã  imposer au dÃ©but des annÃ©es 70. L'exercice relÃ¨ve quoi qu'il arrive du casse-tÃªte. Car il s'agit pour la prÃ©sidente du FN d'Ã©largir son socle Ã©lectoral sans entamer la base qui lui reste acquise.

Pour l'heure, la dÃ©putÃ©e du Pas-de-Calais n'a rien laissÃ© transparaÃ®tre de ses intentions. "J'ai bien pris soin de faire dÃ©poser les noms Ã  l'INPI (NDLR : l'Institut national de la propriÃ©tÃ© intellectuelle) par des gens tellement anonymes que vous ne les trouverez jamais!", a-t-elle mis au dÃ©fi la presse. Voici quelques rÃ¨gles Ã©lÃ©mentaires dont elle devra tenir compte.

RÃ¨gle numÃ©ro 1: contourner le piÃ¨ge de la nouveautÃ© revendiquÃ©e

Selon des sources internes au Front national, le slogan "Pour un nouveau front" n'est pas une piste de travail et c'est tant mieux. Inscrire la nouveautÃ© jusque dans son appellation, c'est l'erreur de dÃ©butant des partis en mal d'inspiration. A sa fondation en 2009, le Nouveau parti anticapitaliste (NPA) d'Olivier Besancenot et Philippe Poutou entendait ainsi tourner la page de ses racines trotskistes en revendiquant sa modernitÃ©. En 2007, HervÃ© Morin avait crÃ©Ã© le Nouveau Centre afin d'acter sa rupture avec FranÃ§ois Bayrou qui avait refusÃ© de choisir entre Nicolas Sarkozy et SÃ©golÃ¨ne Royal. Des choix provisoires qui ont (trop) durÃ© et fini par enfermer les partis dans une modernitÃ© dÃ©suÃ¨te.

RÃ¨gle numÃ©ro 2: Ã©viter les effets de mode!

Comme les vÃªtements, les noms de partis obÃ©issent Ã  des tendances de fond, plus ou moins durables. Comme nous vous l'expliquions au mois de juillet, de nombreux partis ou mouvements ont choisi d'accoler un point d'exclamation Ã  leur appellation. "En Marche!" pour Emmanuel Macron, "Ecologistes!" chez FranÃ§ois de Rugy ou encore "Libres!" chez ValÃ©rie PÃ©cresse... InspirÃ©e des slogans publicitaires, cette innovation typographique vise Ã  se dÃ©marquer des partis traditionnels en impulsant une Ã©nergie, une direction. IdÃ©al pour revendiquer sa spÃ©cificitÃ©, notamment au sein d'un ensemble plus large (l'association de ValÃ©rie PÃ©cresse a vocation Ã  vivre au sein des RÃ©publicains), le procÃ©dÃ© se prÃªte en revanche plutÃ´t mal Ã  une stratÃ©gie de rassemblement. D'autant que le point d'exclamation est inaudible Ã  l'oral. D'oÃ¹ le choix d'Emmanuel Macron, une fois Ã©lu, de transformer la marque En Marche! en un sigle beaucoup plus classique et consensuel: La RÃ©publique En Marche. Pas sÃ»r que Marine Le Pen, qui cherche Ã  fÃ©dÃ©rer plutÃ´t qu'Ã  surprendre, ne cherche Ã  ressusciter le vieux slogan "Le Pen vite!".

RÃ¨gle numÃ©ro 3: rompre avec le passÃ© mais pas trop

Changer de nom pour amorcer un nouveau dÃ©part oui, mais gare Ã  ne pas bousculer ce qui fait la caractÃ©ristique idÃ©ologique du Front national. Si Marine Le Pen veut changer l'image de son parti, pas sÃ»r qu'elle entende revenir sur ses fondamentaux. Son revirement sur la sortie de l'euro et sa volontÃ© manifeste de porter la voix des "enracinÃ©s" marquent au contraire un retour aux sources de la ligne anti-immigration du FN. Dans "Front national", c'est donc le mot front, jugÃ© par certains "anxiogÃ¨ne" et "guerrier", qui pourrait Ãªtre sacrifiÃ© sur l'autel de la nouveautÃ© tandis que le terme "national", plus fÃ©dÃ©rateur et en phase avec la ligne politique du parti, serait conservÃ©.

RÃ¨gle numÃ©ro 4: prendre gare aux contrefaÃ§ons

A quoi bon changer de nom si le crÃ©neau est dÃ©jÃ  occupÃ© par un autre. Si Marine Le Pen veut rassembler, attention Ã  ne pas ressembler Ã  d'autres offres politiques existantes. Le dÃ©part de son ancien numÃ©ro deux Florian Philippot, prÃ©sident des Patriotes, lui interdit dorÃ©navant ce mot qui s'est imposÃ© depuis un quinquennat dans le vocabulaire du FN. Gare Ã©galement Ã  ne pas choisir un nom dont les initiales pourraient prÃªter Ã  la moquerie ou au dÃ©tournement. L'argument a pesÃ© dans le choix de Nicolas Sarkozy de rompre avec l'UMP (dÃ©tournÃ© par le FN en "UMPS") au profit de l'expression "Les RÃ©publicains". Idem pour FranÃ§ois Bayrou qui envisageait Ã  l'origine de nommer le Modem "Parti dÃ©mocrate". Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon a quant Ã  lui dÃ» batailler pour que son Parti de gauche ne devienne pas le "PDG".

RÃ¨gle numÃ©ro 5: rassembler pour rassurer

OubliÃ©s les politiques et les Ã©tiquettes gauche/droite. Les RÃ©publicains, La RÃ©publique En Marche, La France insoumise, Les Patriotes... En pleine recomposition du paysage politique, la tendance est aux mots-valises suffisamment larges et flous pour qu'un maximum de FranÃ§ais puissent s'y reconnaÃ®tre. Le futur ex-Front national, qui entend parler aux "enracinÃ©s" succombera-t-il Ã  l'effet de mode? Pas sÃ»r, croit-on en interne, oÃ¹ la prioritÃ© est de prÃ©parer la future majoritÃ© capable de gouverner le pays. Pendant sa campagne prÃ©sidentielle, Marine Le Pen avait scellÃ© une "alliance patriote et rÃ©publicaine" avec Nicolas Dupont-Aignan. Depuis, comme l'a rÃ©vÃ©lÃ© Challenges, sa sÅ“ur Marie-Caroline a dÃ©posÃ© Ã  l'INPI le sigle "Union nationale". A dÃ©faut de surprendre, L'Union nationale et rÃ©publicaine (ou UNR) aurait au moins le mÃ©rite d'Ãªtre un sacrÃ© pied de nez Ã  l'histoire du FN. En 1958, l'UNR (Union pour la nouvelle rÃ©publique) avait Ã©tÃ© fondÃ©e en pleine crise algÃ©rienne pour soutenir le retour au pouvoir du gÃ©nÃ©ral de Gaulle.

Ã€ voir Ã©galement sur Le HuffPost:

TEXT:
Pretty good for not having a crystal ball, Sports Illustrated.

For the Win pointed out Sunday that the sports magazine predicted that the Houston Astros would win the 2017 World Series â€• back in 2014.

The Astros are four victories shy of making fortune tellers of S.I. after beating the New York Yankees in the American League Championship series to earn a berth in the World Series against the Los Angeles Dodgers beginning Tuesday.

But back when the 2014 article was published that June, the Astros had lost more than 100 games in three straight seasons and were en route to a 70-92 record.

The story lauded the rebuilding strategy of the Astrosâ€™ front office and featured outfielder George Springer on the cover with the out-on-a-limb headline: â€œNext Big Thing ... Your 2017 World Series Champs.â€
TITLE: Sports Illustrated Predicted Astros Would Win 2017 World Series Years Ago

SUMMARY:
It's redemption time for Justin Timberlake.
The 36-year-old pop singer announced on Sunday night that he would headline the 2018 Super Bowl Halftime Show.
Timberlake once had the honor of performing at the event in 2004 with Janet Jackson, a now infamous concert.
During that show, Timberlake accidentally ripped Jackson's top, which resulted in a wardrobe malfunction that revealed the singer's nipple on television.
The "SexyBack" singer enlisted the help of his friend, talk show host Jimmy Fallon, to announce the news in a video.
TEXT:
It's redemption time for Justin Timberlake.

The 36-year-old pop singer announced on Sunday night that he would headline the 2018 Super Bowl Halftime Show. Timberlake once had the honor of performing at the event in 2004 with Janet Jackson, a now infamous concert.

During that show, Timberlake accidentally ripped Jackson's top, which resulted in a wardrobe malfunction that revealed the singer's nipple on television.

But Timberlake now has the chance to create a new memory.

The "SexyBack" singer enlisted the help of his friend, talk show host Jimmy Fallon, to announce the news in a video. Fallon asks repeatedly if Timberlake has the time.

"I do have time," Timberlake answered over and over again.
TITLE: Justin Timberlake To Headline The 2018 Super Bowl Halftime Show

Die tÃ¼rkische Regierung hatte sich schon vor der Offensive demonstrativ hinter Bagdad gestellt. Schon vor dem Referendum hatte es aus Ankara geheiÃŸen, die kurdische Regierung werde einen â€œPreis zahlenâ€, wenn sie ihre UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit erklÃ¤re.

TEXT:
El fiscal general del Estado, JosÃ© Manuel Maza, ha asegurado este lunes que si el presidente de la Generalitat, Carles Puigdemont, declara la independencia, "tendrÃ¡n que ser las Fuerzas y Cuerpos de Seguridad del Estado las que procedan a su detenciÃ³n", ya que "es cuestiÃ³n de las fuerzas de orden pÃºblico".

En declaraciones a Antena 3 recogidas por Europa Press, ha insistido en que "lo de la detenciÃ³n de Puigdemont es algo que ahora mismo" no se plantea ni quiere plantearse y ha afirmado que "cada cosa llegarÃ¡ a su tiempo si tiene que llegar".

Maza ha recordado "una situaciÃ³n semejante de la II RepÃºblica donde las autoridades actuaron cuando se produjo el acto formal de declaraciÃ³n de independencia".

AsÃ­, ha remarcado que "si se plantea un problema de orden pÃºblico" no serÃ¡ competencia suya, sino de "los que tienen competencias y conocimientos para ello" y ha recordado "una situaciÃ³n semejante de la II RepÃºblica donde las autoridades actuaron cuando se produjo el acto formal de declaraciÃ³n de independencia".

"Un hecho trascendente es si llega a declarar la independencia unilateral porque eso consuma todo este trayecto con una gravedad absoluta pero es mejor no adelantarse a los hechos. Yo solo puedo decir que Puigdemont serÃ¡ responsable de sus actos", ha aÃ±adido.

Maza ha aclarado que aunque el presidente autonÃ³mico no haya declarado la independencia, ya ha cometido tres presuntos delitos, que son los de "prevaricaciÃ³n, desobediencia y malversaciÃ³n", por los cuales la FiscalÃ­a "podrÃ­a pedir prisiÃ³n". No obstante, ha explicado que si todavÃ­a no lo ha hecho es porque no han tenido "oportunidad" y prefieren "esperar" a que la magistrada del TSJC, Mercedes Arnas, haya dado todos los pasos correspondientes", como "tomar la declaraciÃ³n de los investigados".

En EspaÃ±a no hay presos polÃ­ticos, sino polÃ­ticos presos que tienen que responder ante la ley.

Con respecto a la decisiÃ³n de la jueza Lamela de ordenar prisiÃ³n sin fianza para los presidentes de Asamblea Nacional Catalana (ANC) y Ã’mnium Cultural, Jordi SÃ nchez y Jordi Cuixart, respectivamente, por un presunto delito de sediciÃ³n, Maza ha negado que se trate de "presos polÃ­ticos" y ha explicado que "en EspaÃ±a no hay presos polÃ­ticos, sino polÃ­ticos presos que tienen que responder ante la ley".

SUMMARY:
By Greg LacourFORT BRAGG, N.C. (Reuters) - Sentencing proceedings start on Monday to determine the fate of U.S. Army Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl, who could face life in prison after pleading guilty to deserting his duties in Afghanistan in June 2009 and endangering the lives of fellow troops.
The 31-year-old Idaho native was quickly captured by the Taliban and spent the next five years suffering torture, abuse and neglect in captivity.
Morita said he believed Bergdahl should be dishonorably discharged and sentenced to as much as life in prison.
US ARMY / Reuters U.S. Army Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl is pictured in this undated handout photo provided by the U.S. Army.
Bergdahl pleaded guilty on Oct. 16 to desertion and misbehavior before the enemy, with the latter offense carrying a possible life sentence.
TEXT:
By Greg Lacour

FORT BRAGG, N.C. (Reuters) - Sentencing proceedings start on Monday to determine the fate of U.S. Army Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl, who could face life in prison after pleading guilty to deserting his duties in Afghanistan in June 2009 and endangering the lives of fellow troops.

The hearing at North Carolinaâ€™s Fort Bragg is expected to include testimony from soldiers injured in the dangerous search for Bergdahl, who walked off his combat outpost in Paktika province to report what he said were â€œcritical problemsâ€ in his chain of command.

The 31-year-old Idaho native was quickly captured by the Taliban and spent the next five years suffering torture, abuse and neglect in captivity. A Taliban prisoner swap that won his release in 2014, organized by the administration of then-Democratic President Barack Obama, was criticized by people in the military and by Republicans.

During last yearâ€™s presidential campaign, Republican Donald Trump called Bergdahl â€œa no-good traitor who should have been executed.â€

Former Army Corporal Jonathan Morita said in a phone interview on Sunday that he may testify this week before Army Judge Colonel Jeffery Nance about his injuries, including one to his hand during a 2009 search operation.

Morita said he believed Bergdahl should be dishonorably discharged and sentenced to as much as life in prison.

â€œA fair sentence, I hope, for his actions and what it created,â€ Morita said.

US ARMY / Reuters U.S. Army Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl is pictured in this undated handout photo provided by the U.S. Army. (U.S. Army/Handout via Reuters)

Navy SEAL Senior Chief James Hatch, shot in the leg during an attempted rescue, is also expected to speak at the hearing, his attorney, Buddy Rake, told KPHO-TV last week. Rake could not be reached on Sunday.

Bergdahl pleaded guilty on Oct. 16 to desertion and misbehavior before the enemy, with the latter offense carrying a possible life sentence. He entered a â€œnaked plea,â€ meaning he does not have an agreement about the sentencing terms with prosecutors.

While the Army will focus on the damage caused by Bergdahlâ€™s actions, his attorneys are likely to present expert testimony about his suffering in captivity in hopes of securing a more lenient sentence, military law experts said.

â€œHe will try to show that he was imprisoned under harsh conditions and was subjected to severe punishment,â€ said Richard Rosen, a professor at Texas Tech Universityâ€™s law school.

Bergdahl, who testified in court that he tried to escape his captors 15 times, admitted wrongdoing but said he never intended to put anyone at risk.

â€œAt the time, I had no thoughts that anyone would come searching for me,â€ said Bergdahl, who remains on active duty in a clerical job at a San Antonio base.
TITLE: U.S. Army Deserter Bowe Bergdahl Faces Life In Prison As Sentencing Hearing Begins

Dans son rapport annuel 2017, on constate une augmentation significative des plaintes dÃ©posÃ©es Ã  son bureau. TEXT:
All'indomani del referendum, il governatore del Veneto, Luca Zaia, chiede che siano riconosciute alla Regione "i privilegi di cui godono le Regioni a Statuto speciale". Una richiesta, da veicolare attraverso una proposta di legge costituzionale, che registra la netta contrarietÃ  del governo. Il sottosegretario Gian Claudio Bressa, Ã¨ perentorio: "Siamo pronti ad aprire un tavolo subito ma la condizione di partenza Ã¨ che le Regioni approvino una legge in attuazione dell'articolo 116 della Costituzione" per chiedere autonomia differenziata. Il problema Ã¨ che oggi Zaia ha fatto approvare in giunta una proposta di modifica costituzionale per inserire il Veneto tra le Regioni a statuto speciale. Ãˆ una proposta non ricevibile dal governo, semmai di competenza del Parlamento".

Grillo: "Vittoria dei cittadini, non possono restare inascoltati. Lega, vergogna"

"Autonomia e partecipazione sono da sempre le stelle polari del M5S. I cittadini di Lombardia e Veneto hanno partecipato, votato e deciso: non possono rimanere inascoltati". Ãˆ quanto scrive il blog di Beppe Grillo in merito al referendum sull'autonomia. "Chi parla di truffa o di soldi buttati fa a pugni con un dato numerico eloquente", attacca il blog secondo il quale "al Pd il voto popolare non piace". E, attacca ancora il M5S, la Lega "si Ã¨ comportata vergognosamente, sventolando il tema dei residui fiscali delle regioni, che con non c'entrano niente".

"Altro che l'inesistente Padania e le bugie che i governi leghisti hanno raccontato per vent'anni ai cittadini. L'autonomia Ã¨ una cosa seria e 5,5 milioni di italiani in Lombardia e Veneto lo hanno ribadito ancora una volta. Grazie al Movimento 5 Stelle si potrÃ  finalmente applicare in pieno la nostra splendida Costituzione: nessuna secessione, nessun isolazionismo, bensÃ¬ l'applicazione dell'articolo 116 che dÃ  la possibilitÃ  di gestire direttamente le risorse su competenze essenziali come il sostegno alle imprese, la ricerca e l'innovazione, l'ambiente, l'istruzione, la valorizzazione dei beni culturali e il governo del territorio, che avvicinate ai territori potranno essere gestite con piÃ¹ razionalitÃ  ed efficacia", prosegue il post del M5S che ricorda: "Neanche un euro verrÃ  tolto agli altri territori, nessuna guerra tra cittadini italiani, alla faccia della Lega e del centro-destra che vorrebbero soffiare sul fuoco della crisi per basse ragioni elettorali".

E, sottolinea il blog di Grillo, "L'affluenza Ã¨ stata alta nonostante la strumentalizzazione della Lega Nord, che non solo ha atteso due anni e mezzo cercando di arrivare il piÃ¹ possibile a ridosso delle elezioni regionali (la proposta del Movimento 5 stelle lombardo per il referendum era stata votata in Consiglio Regionale a febbraio 2015)". Quindi il blog conclude: "Il Movimento, invece, ha preferito l'informazione alla propaganda, spiegando nel dettaglio il contenuto del referendum, l'aderenza alla nostra carta costituzionale e gli effetti del voto. Il nostro obiettivo Ã¨ quello di richiedere al governo tutte le materie concorrenti come previsto dall'art. 117 della Costituzione, coinvolgendo gli enti territoriali. Crediamo che la prioritÃ  debba andare ad alcune aree di grande interesse per il Nord e non solo: l'istruzione, l'ambiente, l'innovazione, lo sviluppo delle imprese e il coordinamento della finanza pubblica e del sistema tributario. Grazie a chi ha votato e capito questi referendum storici: Ã¨ la loro vittoria, non della Lega Nord e dei partiti".

Il dato del veneto, dove l'affluenza ha rasentato il 60%, "Ã¨ un mandato degli elettori di cui ho grande rispetto" per aprire una trattativa sull'autonomia ma "per quanto riguarda la Lombardia parleremo di una sconfitta, nello specifico di una sconfitta di Maroni", ha affermato in una intervista a Repubblica il ministro dell'Agricoltura e vice segretario del Pd Maurizio Martina osservando che "le materie fiscali non sono e non possono essere oggetto di trattativa nÃ© con il Veneto nÃ© con la Lombardia e neanche con l'Emilia Romagna che ha avviato un'interlocuzione con il governo senza passare dal referendum".

Insomma "Zaia e Maroni potranno avviare lo stesso percorso di confronto del presidente Bonaccini" nell'ambito di "una idea federalista equilibrata, cooperativa". "PartirÃ  una discussione e in caso di accordo questo verrÃ  votato dal parlamento con una legge", ha aggiunto Martina.
TITLE: Zaia vuole il Veneto tra le Regioni a statuto speciale. Il Governo chiude: "Ãˆ una provocazione"

SUMMARY:
According to the Chartered Management Institute, men are twice as likely as women to ask for a pay rise - and just as shocking is the fact that three in five women have never even asked.
This is despite the fact that, as highlighted by the Channel Four Dispatches show 'Who Deserves A Pay Rise'?
But you should not shy away from demanding fair pay for the work you do already and the skills you have.
One of the best things you can do to boost your confidence is to role-play your salary negotiation with someone who's successfully asked for a pay rise before.
Good luck in your negotiations - and go get that pay rise!
TEXT:
According to the Chartered Management Institute, men are twice as likely as women to ask for a pay rise - and just as shocking is the fact that three in five women have never even asked. This is despite the fact that, as highlighted by the Channel Four Dispatches show 'Who Deserves A Pay Rise'? this week, it's been 15 years since most British workers saw any real-term pay increase.



So what's stopping you from asking? Now, I understand that some people find talking about money awkward. But you should not shy away from demanding fair pay for the work you do already and the skills you have.



Confidence is the key to your success. But you also need to negotiate from a position of strength. That means knowing what you want out of the bargaining - and what you are worth.



Image: Pixabay



Be clear about your goals



Too many people approach chats about pay rises without enough research. It's particularly important to identify your target salary range and weigh-up your priorities. Check the salaries paid by competitors and use an online salary checker. You have every right to be ambitious - but be realistic: you'll never convince anyone to pay you a fantasy salary.



It's also important to think holistically about what you want. Don't just focus on the salary and benefits. Also think about the career opportunities and your work-life balance.



You need to gather all the important information about the job you do. Understanding the complexity of your role will give you a better view of your market value and being clear about how your in-demand skills will bring extra value to the company will put you in a much stronger negotiating position.



Make sure you know what is most important to you; what benefits you feel you must have and which ones you can live without.





Image: Pixabay

Convince them you're worth it



While it feels hard to do, it's usually best to meet your manager face-to-face to conduct salary negotiations rather than just send an email.



The most important thing is to be prepared and have realistic expectations. Arm yourself with the full knowledge of what you want, and what you'd be prepared to give up. That way you will be able to articulate your position confidently.



A classic negotiation technique is to start by asking for more than you are willing to accept. After all, you can always come down, but you can rarely go up. Above all, avoid confrontation and don't be defensive. Saying the salary's a joke or pleading your financial woes won't win you any favours. Instead, stay calm, respectful and focused.



If you've done your research, you'll have some bargaining chips. Highlight examples of where you have won clients, saved money or mentored a winning team. You could even prepare a portfolio, case studies or testimonials to demonstrate your claims. State your reasons clearly and then stop - let the other person fill the silence.



Try something along the lines of: "I think the added value I've brought to this role could be reflected in my pay. What do you think?" This is more likely to get a positive response than going in with all guns blazing and declaring "I won't take a penny less than Â£xxK!"



Image: Pixabay



Offer more



In order to be paid more, you might need to offer more. Can you prove you can add value beyond what's in the job description? If so, you may be able to persuade them to create a new position or direct you toward a higher-level role. It pays to have researched the typical salary and responsibilities for someone in a job that's one level above.



Know where you can be flexible to achieve a win-win outcome, by determining what is important to the company and to your own career. For example, if the company needs to control payroll expenses, would you be happy to work on a fixed term contract? If they really can't increase the salary, could you work fewer hours for the same pay? A savvy employer might realise the benefit of having your hard-to-find skills for 25 hours a week rather than a less experienced person for 37.



Another option is to agree a date (in writing) for a salary review. This should be after six months rather than a year. But remember, your negotiating power is usually strongest before you sign a revised contract.



All negotiations involve some compromise and you are unlikely to get everything you want. Knowing what is a "must have" versus a "nice to have" will help you make the right decisions. Don't push too hard - you don't want to push yourself out of a job - and be sure to ask your employer to confirm everything you've negotiated during your meetings in writing.



Image: Pixabay

Be assertive



Assertiveness is essential for successful negotiations. One of the best things you can do to boost your confidence is to role-play your salary negotiation with someone who's successfully asked for a pay rise before.



Even if it makes you feel uncomfortable, you must be prepared to market yourself to get the salary you deserve. Above all, never underestimate your value. Good luck in your negotiations - and go get that pay rise!
TITLE: How To Ask For A Pay Rise

"Mischung aus ZÃ¶gerlichkeit und Ãœberreaktion"

SpÃ¤testens seit dem 9. November 2015 wisse Rajoy, dass die Separatisten mit der Abspaltung Kataloniens ernst machen wollen: An jenem Tag erklÃ¤rte das damals frisch gewÃ¤hlte Regionalparlament feierlich, die AblÃ¶sung von Spanien in Gang setzen zu wollen.
